tossups.question: This site was the original location of a painting depicting a man with red lips and eyebrows and a grey man with no visible eyes, titled Kings of Freedom. A 2016 parody of an artwork from this place was titled Make Everything Great Again and featured world leaders Donald Trump and Vladimir Putin. Washington, D.C.’s Newseum houses the largest surviving art installation from this place in the US, which is on display next to a reconstructed (*) guard tower. A famous photograph was satirized in a work painted here titled My God, Help Me to Survive This Deadly Love, which shows Leonid Brezhnev kissing Erich Honecker, who led the country that this edifice was built in. For 10 points, name this graffiti-covered barrier between the two halves of a German city.
tossups.answer: Berlin Wall [prompt on Berlin or East Germany] <VC, OVisArt>

tossups.question: A character in this play recalls that, while sailing, he felt like he “became the sun, the hot sand, green seaweed anchored to a rock,” and wished that he had been born “as a seagull or a fish.” In the same scene from this play, that character’s father regrets allowing himself to be typecast in exchange for money. A woman in this play has hands that are afflicted with (*) rheumatism and complains to Cathleen about the sounding of a foghorn. While that woman in this play was pregnant with Eugene, who died of measles, Doctor Hardy’s prescription made her become addicted to morphine. For 10 points, James, Edmund, Jamie, and Mary are members of the Tyrone family in what play by Eugene O’Neill?
tossups.answer: Long Day’s Journey into Night <RY, Drama>
acceptable: Long Day’s Journey into Night <RY, Drama>

tossups.question: A number of newspaper columns by this economist were collected into the book Bright Promises, Dismal Performance. This economist created a public TV series to respond to another thinker’s TV series The Age of Uncertainty and coined the term “helicopter drop” for a policy response suitable to times of crisis. Based on research of the Great Depression, this economist argued that the whole Federal Reserve should be replaced with a rule that the (*) money supply grow by a fixed “k” percent each year. Protests broke out in 1976 when this economist was awarded a Nobel Prize due to his pupils’ work with Augusto Pinochet’s government. With his wife Rose, this monetarist wrote Capitalism and Freedom. For 10 points, name this Chicago School economist.
tossups.answer: Milton Friedman <WA, SocSci>

tossups.question: A writer imagined that a holder of this office would restore order to the world as “Alto Arrigo.” The body of a holder of this office was preserved in vinegar so that it could be interred in Jerusalem, but was buried in Antioch. A religiously tolerant holder of this office who spoke six languages, including Arabic and Greek, was called “stupor mundi” by contemporaries; he and his grandfather of the same name were believed to (*) sleep beneath the Kyffhauser mountains. This office’s holders were given a crown that supposedly contained a nail from the True Cross, the Iron Crown of Lombardy. Dante placed an eccentric Sicilian man with this title in the Sixth Circle, even though as a Guelph he backed this office’s holder against the Pope. For 10 points, name this elected position held by Frederick Barbarossa.
tossups.answer: Holy Roman Emperor [or Romanorum Imperator; prompt on emperor or Kaiser or King of Germany; do not accept or prompt on “Roman emperor”] <AF, ContHist>
tossups.answer_formatted: Holy Roman Emperor [or Romanorum Imperator; prompt on emperor or Kaiser or King of Germany; do not accept or prompt on "“Roman emperor”"]

tossups.question: Consecutive series of systems with this many members separated by a factor of 22.7 in a “Russian nesting doll structure” are called Efimov states. The simplest subunits of propellanes have this many carbons. A test for methyl ketones forms a yellow precipitate of molecules with this many halogen atoms. Iodomethane and zinc react with alkenes to form a ring with this many members in the (*) Simmons–Smith reaction. A “butterfly mechanism” reaction forms epoxides, which are comprised of this many atoms. Aluminum has this many valence electrons. Nitrogen must form this many bonds to complete its octet. There are this many p orbitals for each energy level after the first. For 10 points, name this number of carbons in propane and atomic number of lithium.
tossups.answer: three [or 3; accept plus 3 or positive 3; do not accept or prompt on “minus 3” or “negative 3”] <JL, Chem>
tossups.answer_formatted: three [or 3; accept plus 3 or positive 3; do not accept or prompt on "“minus 3”" or "“negative 3”"]

tossups.question: In a backstory from this work, a character is stung by a bee on the thigh while fanning his mentor, who only agreed to teach him because he was a priest. In this work, a mother commands her sons to “share the fruit equally” after falsely hearing that they won fruit in a competition. In one of this work’s pivotal duels, a character ignores the rules of war and shoots an opponent who is stuck in the mud trying to move a (*) wheel. Its core conflict is set in motion when several men are exiled for losing a game of dice. In a famous dialogue within [emphasize] this epic, a character’s blue-skinned charioteer explains to him that he shouldn’t care about killing enemies like Karna on the great plain of Kurukshetra. For 10 points, the Kauravas and Pandavas fight a great war in what Hindu epic?
tossups.answer: The Mahabharata [prompt on Kurukshetra War until “epic” is read; do not accept or prompt on “Bhagavad Gita” since that’s not an epic] <WA, Myth>
tossups.answer_formatted: The Mahabharata [prompt on Kurukshetra War until “epic” is read; do not accept or prompt on "“Bhagavad Gita”" since that’s not an epic]

tossups.question: This composer’s first piano concerto originated as a sonata for two pianos, then became a symphony before taking final form. A series of descending thirds in E minor opens a symphony by this composer that was cited by Arnold Schoenberg as an example of why he was a “Progressive.” This composer’s “F A-flat F” motif referred to him being (*) “free, but happy.” Unusually, this 19th-century composer ended his last symphony in E minor with a passacaglia based on a Bach chaconne [shuh-CON]. Hans von Bülow called this composer’s first symphony “Beethoven’s 10th.” For 10 points, name this German composer of four symphonies, the Academic Festival Overture, and a famous Lullaby.
tossups.answer: Johannes Brahms <EX, Music>

tossups.question: A 2016 study by Nicole Boivin et al. dated a migration across this body of water to around 700 to 1000 AD based on the planting of mung bean and cotton. Sailors on this body of water gave a name meaning “the moon” to islands where Shikomori is spoken. It’s not a strait, but trade in this body of water was the main purpose of the creation of the VOC [V-O-C] and was why the Mamluks launched an expedition to Diu [dyew]. (*) Long-distance trade across this body spurred the development of boats called dhow [“dow”] and spread the modern-day Shirazi people from the city of Shiraz. At the apex of its power, the Chola dynasty controlled much of this body of water, which was crossed by ancestors of the Malagasy people. For 10 points, the port of Goa is on a branch of what major world ocean?
tossups.answer: Indian Ocean [accept Arabian Sea or Bay of Bengal specifically] <WA, WorldHist>
tossups.answer_formatted: Indian Ocean [accept Arabian Sea or Bay of Bengal specifically]

tossups.question: This character’s observation of a man and woman “squirting water out of their mouths” is analyzed in Harold Bloom’s 1990 collection of essays on the novel he appears in. This character observes that a school’s promise to create “clear-thinking young men” is “strictly for the birds.” While discussing Isak Dinesen’s Out of Africa, this character notes that “I’m quite illiterate, but I read a lot” before explaining what (*) “knocks [him] out” about books. After getting drunk, he goes to Central Park to watch the ducks that he discussed with the cab driver Mr. Horwitz. This character’s use of the phrase “screw up” helped popularize it in English. He treasures a baseball mitt with green ink writing that belonged to his brother Allie. For 10 points, a school of “phonies” is resented by what J. D. Salinger protagonist?
tossups.answer: Holden Caulfield [accept either underlined portion] <WA, LongFic>

tossups.question: Blue goo is a type of this substance with a high serpentinite content found in Northern California. Minerals like smectite and montmorillonite in this substance impact its shrink-swell capacity. Needle ice can be a precursor to frost heaving occurring in this substance. Climate, relief, and time are among the factors in the development of this substance that are represented in the mnemonic (*) CLORPT. The movement of air and water through this substance is increased through pedoturbation. Excessive rain can cause leaching to occur in this substance. The organic component of this substance is called humus [HYOOM-us] and is more prevalent in its O and A horizons. For 10 points, name this substance, a variable mixture of sand, silt, and clay whose “top” variety has nutrients for plant growth.
tossups.answer: soil [accept topsoil; prompt on clay until “needle ice” is read] <AF, EarthSci>
tossups.answer_formatted: soil [accept topsoil; prompt on clay until “needle ice” is read]

tossups.question: Two forms of this protein absorb light equally at an isosbestic [iso-S’BEST-ic] point of around 800 nanometers. The change between those two forms of this protein is detected by a T2-weighted signal in BOLD [bold] contrast, which is utilized by fMRI [F-M-R-I]. Histidine residues are pulled a fraction of an angstrom towards the plane of structures made of four pyrroles when this protein binds its substrate. This protein experiences (*) cooperativity as its substrate binds to each of its four subunits, resulting in a binding curve with a sigmoidal shape. A mutation that adds a valine residue to this protein causes the cells that contain it to have a sickle shape. For 10 points, name this protein that carries oxygen in red blood cells.
tossups.answer: hemoglobin <RY, Biology>

tossups.question: Romans 13:9 states that exhibiting this concept is “fulfilling the law.” Psalm 136 states that this aspect of God “endures forever.” Jesus says that people will “know” his supporters by this concept. In response to Jesus questioning Peter three times about this concept, Jesus tells him to “Feed my sheep.” Benedict XVI’s first encyclical is titled for this concept. In John 15, “To lay down one’s life for a friend” is the greatest example of this concept. This concept is called (*) “the greatest” of three theological virtues, along with faith and hope, in 1 Corinthians 13; that passage also says that this virtue “is patient” and “is kind.” For 10 points, agape [AH-gah-pay] is an example of what virtue that is strengthened in the sacrament of marriage?
tossups.answer: love [accept charity; accept “his steadfast love endures forever” or “do you love me [Jesus]” or “God is love”; anti-prompt (ask “can you be less specific?”) on specific kinds of love like eros, agape, and philia] <JL, Rel>
tossups.answer_formatted: love [accept charity; accept “his steadfast love endures forever” or “do you love me [Jesus]

tossups.question: This author wrote an anonymous essay objecting that contemporary novels intended for women were “silly” and proposed a more realistic vision of the novel in “The Natural History of German Life.” Ludwig Feuerbach’s idea of Christianity influenced this author, who translated Feuerbach and Spinoza into English. In a novel by this author, kabbalah terms are used to describe a meeting along the Thames with Mordecai. In another novel by this author, a bag of stolen gold is found at the bottom of a (*) pit with the skeleton of Dunstan. This author wrote about a young Jewish man in Germany who loves Gwendolen Harleth in one novel, and another about a man who adopts Godfrey’s daughter Eppie. For 10 points, name this author of Daniel Deronda and Silas Marner.
tossups.answer: George Eliot [or Mary Anne Evans] <WA, OtherLit>

tossups.question: Shortly before this man’s death, he delivered a speech at the Pratt Institute chronicled by his friend Dore Ashton about art’s necessary “preoccupation with death.” This artist and Kenneth Noland cited Matisse’s L’atelier rouge [lah-tull-YAY rooj] as a precursor to their style of composition. A building decorated with works by this man is found next to the Menil Collection in Houston and contains 14 works done in a brown and black style. This artist’s “mythomorphic” phase gave way to works such as No. 61: Rust and (*) Blue and Four Darks in Red, which he claimed were not abstractionist, but spiritual. This artist’s Seagram Murals for the Four Seasons restaurant were left unfinished. For 10 points, name this post-war American artist, an archetypal painter of the Color Field school born in Latvia.
tossups.answer: Mark Rothko [accept Rothko Chapel] <EX, Painting>

tossups.question: Seven earls wrote to Boniface VIII to defend a king’s right to rule this kingdom in the 1301 Barons’ Letter. In 1418, Charles VII became the first French king to employ an elite garde of troops from this kingdom. After beginning his military career by assassinating the sheriff of Lanark, a knight from this kingdom achieved his greatest victory by defeating a force under John de Warenne and Hugh de Cressingham as it crossed a (*) bridge over the River Forth. This kingdom was traditionally allied with France in the Auld Alliance. Edward I was known as the “Hammer” of the people of this region and crushed its armies at the Battle of Falkirk. For 10 points, name this northern region of the British Isles governed from Edinburgh and home to William Wallace.
tossups.answer: (Kingdom of) Scotland [accept Alba] <AF, BritHist>

tossups.question: This politician won a California primary after an opponent left his wife and family to marry a socialite and staffer with whom he had an affair. In The New Yorker interview, this politician said that he had asked his friend Curtis LeMay about UFOs at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base. This man become the subject of an ad starring William Bogert, four years after he wrote a book that was actually ghost-written by William F. Buckley’s brother-in-law. He was backed in the speech (*) “A Time for Choosing” by Ronald Reagan. The phrase “In your guts you know he’s nuts” parodied this politician’s slogan in an election in which he was targeted by an ad showing a nuclear attack, the “Daisy” ad. For 10 points, what author of The Conscience of a Conservative lost the 1964 presidential election?
tossups.answer: Barry Morris Goldwater <LS, AmHist>

tossups.question: In the parody dialogue Menexenus, which presents a critique of this subject, Socrates claims to have had Aspasia as his teacher. Isocrates founded a school of itinerant teachers of this subject who roamed Attica. The five “canons” of this subject, often modeled on the teachings of Quintilian, included inventio and dispositio. Poetry is considered to be a specialized type of this subject in the (*) Gorgias. Grammar, logic, and this subject formed the trivium in medieval education. Instead of using philosophy, one could achieve arete through this subject according to the Sophists, who were known for their strategies of using it. Aristotle’s treatise on this subject discusses ethos, logos, and pathos, and defines it as the ability to see the available means of persuasion. For 10 points, name this formal art of discourse.
tossups.answer: rhetoric [accept oration or oratory art or discourse until “teachers” and prompt after; prompt on speaking or speech or argument] <WA, PhilO>
tossups.answer_formatted: rhetoric [accept oration or oratory art or discourse until “teachers” and prompt after; prompt on speaking or speech or argument]

tossups.question: The speaker of a poem enjoins the reader to ride away on this thing “to a divine, fairy-like heaven.” This thing sings “from my prison of glass with its scarlet wax seals” in a poem titled for its “soul.” This thing is the second item listed in a stanza that ends “Oh, Wilderness were Paradise enow!” This thing, along with “death” and (*) “revolt,” titles a section of a poetry collection that includes “Spleen and Ideal.” It is listed with “a Book of Verses underneath the Bough” and “a Loaf of Bread – and Thou” in the Rubaiyat of Omar Khayyam. For 10 points, name this drink that, in Charles Baudelaire’s The Flowers of Evil, appears in two poems addressed to Bacchus.
tossups.answer: wine [or vin; or alcohol] <JM, Poetry>

tossups.question: A museum in this metropolis was founded by the British-Armenian oil magnate Calouste Gulbenkian. Poets in this city frequented a café in its Chiado [shee-AH-doo] neighborhood, whose Bertrand bookstore is the oldest bookstore in the world. Pastel de nata is an egg tart originating from a part of this city where its iconic Tower of Belem is located. This city built the longest bridge in Europe for its hosting of Expo 98. (*) Humberto Delgado Airport serves this city, whose lower town, or Baixa [BYE-shah], is named after the Marquess of Pombal. This port lies on the mouth of the Tagus River, which the longest in Iberia. For 10 points, what city is the capital of Portugal?
tossups.answer: Lisbon [or Lisboa] <RY, Geo>

tossups.question: Whittaker functions can be used to solve the Schrödinger equation for this scientist’s namesake potential. As alkali metals are immersed in water, their valence electrons are solvated, causing the atoms to violently separate in an explosion named for this scientist. To enable fusion to occur at temperatures below 10-to-the-tenth kelvins, quantum tunneling is used to surpass this scientist’s “barrier.” Collections of particles governed by this scientist’s law cannot be (*) stationary by Earnshaw’s theorem. The constant 8.99 times 10-to-the-ninth newton meters-squared per [his namesake unit]-squared appears in this scientist’s law, which multiplies the magnitude of two charges and is divided by their distance squared. For 10 points, what physicist is the namesake of the SI unit of charge?
tossups.answer: Charles-Augustin de Coulomb <JL, Phys> IF THE GAME IS TIED AT THIS POINT, READ A QUESTION FROM THE TIEBREAKER PACKET. THEN, FOLLOW THE INSTRUCTIONS IN THE TIEBREAKER PACKET. Bonuses
tossups.answer_formatted: Charles-Augustin de Coulomb <JL, Phys> IF THE GAME IS TIED AT THIS POINT, READ A QUESTION FROM THE TIEBREAKER PACKET. THEN, FOLLOW THE INSTRUCTIONS IN THE TIEBREAKER PACKET. Bonuses
acceptable: Charles-Augustin de Coulomb <JL, Phys> IF THE GAME IS TIED AT THIS POINT, READ A QUESTION FROM THE TIEBREAKER PACKET. THEN, FOLLOW THE INSTRUCTIONS IN THE TIEBREAKER PACKET. Bonuses

bonuses.leadin: An entire chapter of anthropologist Heather Levi’s The World of Lucha Libre is dedicated to the use of these objects. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these objects, often wagered by Mexican wrestlers in luchas de apuestas, which require the loser to permanently remove his and the identity that goes with it. They’re also used in many African religions.
This anthropologist wrote The Way of the Masks about their use among the peoples of the Pacific Northwest. He described depressing journeys in the developing world in Tristes Tropiques.

The False Face Society among this group wore red or black painted masks as they healed people. Lewis Henry Morgan wrote an ethnography of this group and named one of his types of kinship systems after them.

bonuses.leadin: A dolly zoom in this film emphasizes the intimidating stature of the protagonist’s rival, Sugar Ray Robinson. For 10 points each:
answers: mirror (The last scene in Taxi Driver) <RY, OVisArt>
parts: Name this film about the boxer Jake LaMotta, who is played by Robert de Niro.

In the last scene of the film, LaMotta delivers a monologue that Marlon Brando gave in On the Waterfront. Even more iconic is Brando’s line “I’m gonna make him an offer he can’t refuse” from this other film.

In Raging Bull, LaMotta delivers the “I coulda been a contender” monologue using one of these objects. In the last scene of another film, a man uses one of these objects to talk to Betsy, who volunteers for Senator Palantine.
metadata: The last scene in Taxi Driver

bonuses.leadin: Edward Ferrero’s United States Colored Troops suffered heavily in the aftermath of this battle, since they were inadequately trained for an experimental assault. For 10 points each:
answers: Battle of Antietam [accept Battle of Sharpsburg]
parts: Name this 1864 Civil War battle that Ulysses Grant called “the saddest affair I have witnessed in this war.” It took place during the Petersburg campaign.

The Battle of the Crater was the brainchild of Ambrose Burnside, who became the namesake of a bridge in this 1862 Maryland battle in which his soldiers failed several times to cross said bridge. It was the bloodiest single day in the Civil War, though Gettysburg claimed more lives.

After his defeat at Fredericksburg, Burnside attempted to revive the morale of his men by planning this aborted offensive. It was named after the poor weather that prevented Burnside’s men from crossing the Rappahannock.

bonuses.leadin: These enzymes can be activated by proteins with CARD [card] domains. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this class of enzymes that act as cysteine proteases. They are activated by diverse stimuli like ER stress, or binding by the Fas [fass] ligand, by TNF, or by granzyme B, to activate their namesake signaling cascades.
Certain caspases are activated by the release of cytochrome C from the mitochondria, as part of this process of programmed cell death.
Caspases were discovered in C. elegans, a model organism that is a member of this phylum. This phylum also includes many parasites, like hookworms.

bonuses.leadin: A character states “I want the best you have” while purchasing this substance, after which she is told that this will “kill anything up to an elephant.” For 10 points each:
answers: barn fire [or barn burning; or equivalents; prompt on fire by asking “a fire in where?”] <JM, Short>
parts: Identify this substance. Though Ms. Grierson claims it is “for rats,” it is actually used on a man who is seen dead next to a single strand of grey hair at the end of a story.
Arsenic is used to poison Homer Barron in “A Rose for Emily,” a story by this Southern author who wrote about Anse Bundren’s quest for false teeth in As I Lay Dying.

Many of Faulkner’s short stories feature Colonel Sartoris, whose father Abner is accused of causing one of these events in a story named after them. Darl attempts to save a coffin during one of these events in As I Lay Dying.
answers_formatted: barn fire [or barn burning; or equivalents; prompt on fire by asking “a fire in where?”]
promptable: fire by asking “a fire in where?”

bonuses.leadin: These items were called “candida” when treated with chalk and were used by those seeking political office, giving English its word “candidate.” For 10 points each:
answers: purple [accept Tyrian purple, Phoenician purple, royal purple, or imperial purple; accept indigo since the major component of Tyrian purple dye was the compound 6,6-dibromoindigo]
Pliny the Elder [prompt on partial answer] <AF, Ancient>
parts: Identify these items that could be used by Roman women until replaced by the stola by the first century BC.

A toga praetexta [pry-TEX-tah], worn primarily by freeborn boys before reaching manhood, contained a stripe of this color, often associated with royalty. Porphyrogénnētos was a Byzantine epithet meaning “born in [this color],” which in antiquity was primarily produced from Murex sea snails.
This Roman writer described the process of creating Tyrian purple dye in his most famous work. This man died while attempting to save people at Stabiae [stah-bee-eye].
answers_formatted: purple [accept Tyrian purple, Phoenician purple, royal purple, or imperial purple; accept indigo since the major component of Tyrian purple dye was the compound 6,6-dibromoindigo]
acceptable: Tyrian purple, Phoenician purple, royal purple,

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about female poets and their husbands, for 10 points each.
parts: This man, who was married to the author of the collection Ariel, wrote “the dreamer in her had fallen in love with me” about his other wife Assia Wevill in the collection Birthday Letters.
This poet was married to the author of a collection titled The Quiver. She wrote about spending “seventeen months in the prison lines” in a section titled “Instead of a Preface.”
In “To My Dear and Loving Husband,” this poet wrote that she prized her husband’s love more than “mines of gold” and “all riches of the East” in The Tenth Muse, lately Sprung up in America.

bonuses.leadin: These constructs are used to solve classic problems like the block on a ramp, the block on a pulley system, and, everyone’s favorite, the block on another block. For 10 points each:
answers: free body diagram [or FBD; or force diagram]
static coefficient of friction [prompt on mu or mu-static]
parts: Name these constructs that depict a problem setup as a series of connected objects with arrows attached to them showing all of the forces and torques on the objects.

As long as a block on a slope of angle theta is stationary, the static version of this quantity is equal to the tangent of theta, irrespective of the mass of the block. The product of normal force and this quantity gives the strength of a certain resistive force.

The coefficient of static friction is always greater than the coefficient of kinetic friction because of these small imperfections in surfaces that shrink the effective contact area. These things thus heighten pressure between the surfaces, causing them to begin to weld together.

bonuses.leadin: The philosophy of “presuppositionalism” asserts that the answer to this philosophical question must be “yes,” because otherwise none of philosophy is rational. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this question. The Baron d’Holbach took a negative position on this philosophical question, while quinque viae [kwin-kway WEE-eye], or “five ways,” affirm a positive answer to it.
This British philosopher introduced his namesake “teapot” thought experiment while questioning the existence of God in Why I Am Not A Christian.

Richard Dawkins’s definition of a “strong theist” cites this man’s quote “I do not believe, I know” regarding God’s existence as an example. His writings on religious philosophy include Modern Man In Search of a Soul and Answer to Job.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about the Bone Wars, a period of ruthlessly competitive fossil hunting in 19th-century America, for 10 points each.
parts: Much of the Bone Wars centered on the Morrison Formation in this least populous US state, which also contains most of Yellowstone National Park.
Among the species unearthed during the wars was this large carnivore, whose name means “Other Lizard.” It thrived in the mid-Jurassic, around 150 million years ago.

The Bone Wars heated up when a man with this surname sent fossil hunters west to enrich his Harvard Museum of Natural History. His Swiss father of the same surname founded the museum, and was a naturalist who opposed Darwinian evolution and wrote A Journey in Brazil.

bonuses.leadin: At the end of this novel’s section “Calypso,” a man poops while reading from a literary journal, and wipes his butt with a page from a prize-winning story. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this novel set entirely on June 16, 1904. Its last chapter is a soliloquy delivered by an opera singer who is having an affair with Blazes Boylan.
Ulysses was written by this man, who also wrote about Stephen Dedalus growing up and leaving Ireland for France in his novel A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man.
In her soliloquy, Molly Bloom repeats this word many times while recalling how Leopold “kissed me under the Moorish wall.” This is the very last word in Ulysses.

bonuses.leadin: One author imagined these people as a matriarchal society who were led by moon priestesses of a great Triple Goddess in conflict with marauding Greek tribes. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these people, thought by actual ancient Greeks to be the original inhabitants of Hellas. In The Clouds, Aristophanes alludes to Athenian belief in descent from these people, as well as a folk etymology of their name meaning “birds.”
This author imagined a “Pelasgian creation myth” in which the goddess Eurynome [yur-uh-NOH-mee] made the world from a great cosmic egg. He wrote The White Goddess and The Greek Myths.
Similarly, many worshippers of this mythical Thracian believed that the world was created from a great cosmic egg. This bard went to the underworld to retrieve Eurydice.

bonuses.leadin: Increasing the temperature of a reaction is one way to ensure that this product is formed rather than a less stable, but easier to form product. For 10 points each:
answers: pi bond [or conjugated pi system or pi orbital]
s-cis [prompt on cis; do not accept or prompt on “s-trans”] <JL, Chem>
parts: Name this reaction product, contrasted with the kinetic product.

The Diels–Alder reaction usually produces an endo kinetic product because the groups attached to the dienophile line up with this type of bond in the diene. A double bond is formed by a sigma bond and one of these bonds also named for a Greek letter.

Cyclic dienes can enhance the Diels–Alder reaction rate by locking the double bonds in this conformation. The two parts of this conformation name refer to the orientation of the double bonds and the central reference bond.
answers_formatted: s-cis [prompt on cis; do not accept or prompt on "“s-trans”"]

bonuses.leadin: Movements in the London Sketchbooks might have been written for use in compositions of this type. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this genre. The 18th and last of the works of this type by a certain composer is sometimes nicknamed “The Trumpet” for its horn-inspired opening. Max Reger [RAY-guh] used the 11th of those works of this type for his Variations and Fugue on a Theme of that composer.
Mozart’s first piano sonata is written in this characteristically easy major key, which has no sharps or flats.
Give the three-word title of the finale of Mozart’s Piano Sonata No. 11, which uses pedal technique and other methods to imitate the sound of military bands.

bonuses.leadin: This city was a free port governed under UN auspices from 1947 until 1954. For 10 points each:
answers: Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia <AF, ContHist>
parts: Name this city whose status was finally settled by the 1975 Treaty of Osimo. It was identified as the southern endpoint of the Iron Curtain in a speech by Winston Churchill.
This man actively sought to acquire Trieste for his country after World War II. He is more famous for being the first Secretary-General of the Non-Aligned Movement.

Tito sought to unite all South Slavic peoples in this state, which came close to joining with Bulgaria before Tito’s split with Stalin. This state’s breakup in the 1990s created countries like Slovenia, Serbia, and Croatia.
acceptable: Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia <AF, ContHist>

bonuses.leadin: In a novel with this title, John Ames dislikes Jack Boughton until he learns that Jack married a black woman named Della, and is hiding it from his father, Reverend Boughton. For 10 points each:
parts: Give the name of the theocratic state ruled by the Sons of Jacob in another novel. In that republic with this name, a woman imagines killing the Commander after playing a game of Scrabble.
The Republic of Gilead is where Offred [“of-Fred”] is a handmaid, whose purpose is to bear children, in this Canadian author’s novel The Handmaid’s Tale.
Gilead is a Pulitzer-winning novel by this author, forming a trilogy with Home and Lila. The town of Fingerbone, Idaho, is the setting of this writer’s first novel, Housekeeping.

bonuses.leadin: One of these works done on fruitwood is named for the flowers held up by a baby boy in the center, and not on the hue in the mother’s cheeks. For 10 points each:
answers: School of Athens [accept Scuola di Atene]
parts: Name these paintings by a specific artist, one “of the Pinks.” That artist also painted versions of those paintings “of the Meadow” and ones named for Sistine and Ansidei.
Raphael may be best known for this monumental fresco located in the Vatican’s Stanza della Segnatura [sen-yah-TOO-rah] that shows Plato and Aristotle at the center of a gathering of intellectuals.

Raphael also painted a stern-looking portrait of Elisabetta, a patron of his from this Mantuan royal family. Andrea Mantegna [mon-TANE-yah] painted a group of red-hatted members of this family holding court under its Ludovico II.

bonuses.leadin: A prolonged one of these events is the most widely accepted cause for the decline of Classical Mayan civilization. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this type of event, through which the city of Lamanai was able to persist due to the nearby New River. One of these climatic events in the 1930s created the Dust Bowl.

Some scholars believe that cities of the northern Yucatán survived the Classic Maya Collapse partly due to their access to seafood. One resource gathered from the sea by the Maya were these items, a variety of which was used as currency in ancient China and West Africa.
Along with caves, these natural features were considered sacred by the Maya as entrances to Xibalba [shee-ball-BAH] and were often used for human sacrifices.

bonuses.leadin: In an article about managing research towards “greatness,” this scientist says that those who have achieved it “generally report, privately, that it is better than wine, the opposite sex, and song put together.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this mathematician whose namesake distance is the number of points at which two strings of equal length differ; that distance measure is less robust than ones named for Levenshtein and Damerau.
Hamming distances can be used to construct these objects in which different species branch off at different points based on their evolutionary relationships.
The relation of the Hamming metric with the space of all possible words is analogous to the problem of packing these perfectly round, three-dimensional solids.

bonuses.leadin: Although this policy has roots among 19th-century thinkers such as Morteza Ansari, its absolute form has been cited by the government of Iran as justification for authoritarian theocracy. For 10 points each:
answers: Guardianship of the (Islamic) Jurist [or Wilayat al-Faqih; or Velayat-e-Faqih; accept word forms such as Governance of the Jurist]
verses of the Qur’an [prompt on verses; do not accept or prompt on “chapters” or “suras”] <VC, Rel>
parts: Name this controversial Shia doctrine that states that experts in Islamic law are supposed to act as custodians for the population.
Absolute Guardianship of the Jurist was advanced by this thinker, whose fatwas encouraged Muslims to oppose chemical weapons, treat transgender people fairly, and murder Salman Rushdie.
The title “Ayatollah” translates as “the sign of God.” Ayat is a word used to designate these things, one of which is known as “al-Kursi” and occurs in al-Baqarah.
answers_formatted: verses of the Qur’an [prompt on verses; do not accept or prompt on "“chapters”" or "“suras”"]
